Beijing 101407 China To find ternary Cu-based catalysts (Cu/Cu2O/CuO) compositions with the highest M2 selectivity(SM2) in Rochow-Müller reaction, a machine learning (ML) framework including prediction and optimization models was created. The Stacking integration approach was used to describe the relationship between the catalyst's structures features and SM2 for prediction model. Further, the composition space was effectively searched for compositions with the highest SM2 by optimization model with the genetic algorithm (GA) in the base of prediction model. Finally, the greatest SM2 catalyst compositions were effectively suggested by the ML framework, and the constructed catalyst had an SM2 of 82.35%, with a relative error of only 0.93% from the predicted value. ML model combined with experimental characterization was used to infer the synergistic mechanism of the ternary Cu-based catalysts. Cu/Cu2O and Cu2O/CuO contact surfaces can create heterojunction and Schottky junction structures, respectively, to facilitate the transport of electron-hole pairs and the formation of active spices. ML framework achieved compositional optimization of catalysts and were successfully integrated with materials science theory. Graphical Abstract Keywords Rochow reaction Machine learning Composition optimization M2 selectivity Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The Rochow-Müller reaction, sometimes referred to as the direct synthesis, is the principal method used to create methylchlorosilanes, which have been considered to be the most important component in the techniques used to produce silicones [1–3]. Eq. 1 illustrates the Rochow-Müller reaction process. This procedure results in the production of a number of chemicals, such as methyltrichlorosilane (M1), dimethyldichlorosilane (M2), trimethylchlorosilane (M3), methyldichlorosilane (M1H), and dimethylchlorosilane (M2H), as well as various low and high boiling constituents. Among the above products, M2 is the most widely used silicone monomer in the silicone industry, accounting for 90% of the total usage of silicone monomers. Under the status of current development, any improvement of M2 selectivity(SM2) that can be stabilized in silicone industrial production will generate significant economic benefits [4]. Therefore, to improve the yield of M2 monomer is crucial to the development of the silicone industry. (1) Si + CH 3 Cl ⟶ catalyst CH 3 SiCl 3 ( M1 ) Si + CH 3 Cl ⟶ catalyst ( CH 3 ) 2 SiCl 2 ( M2 ) Si + CH 3 Cl ⟶ catalyst ( CH 3 ) 3 SiCl 3 ( M3 ) Si + CH 3 Cl ⟶ catalyst CH 3 HSiCl 3 ( M1H ) Si + CH 3 Cl ⟶ catalyst ( CH 3 ) 2 HSiCl ( M2H ) other low and high boiling residue The kind and structure of Cu-based catalysts play a significant role in determining SM2 and silicon conversion(CSi). According to certain reports, metallic copper and other copper compositions, such as CuO [5], Cu2O [6], CuCl [7], and Cu-Cu2O-CuO [8], can operate as efficient catalysts for the Rochow-Müller reaction, advancing the process and enhancing SM2 and CSi. Due to its best SM2 and yield among them, a catalyst constructed of ternary Cu-Cu2O-CuO composites is regarded as the most appropriate Rochow-Müller catalyst [9]. It is commonly accepted that the exceptional catalytic performance of Cu-Cu2O-CuO catalysts is attributed to the synergetic effect induced by the contact between Cu, Cu2O, and CuO [10,11]. It is widely acknowledged that the structure features of Cu-Cu2O-CuO catalysts have a significant impact on the catalytic performance, even if it is still unclear how the synergetic effect during the reaction process works. In addition to the ternary compositions, elements such as Zn, Sn, and P [12] are usually added as promoters to the catalyst system. These elements have no catalytic effect when used as main catalysts, but they can promote the catalytic performance of ternary catalysts when added to the catalytic system at low concentrations [13].Numerous studies have been published in recent years that aim to increase the catalytic activity of Cu-Cu2O-CuO catalysts by altering their chemical composition [12,14], particle size [13,15], and morphology [9]. However, the combined effect of multiple compositions makes the catalytic system very complex, which makes the progress of theoretical studies on the catalytic mechanism rather slow. The development and optimization of novel ternary Cu-based catalysts lack a theoretical basis due to the unclear catalytic mechanism. Current research on ternary Cu catalysts is often limited to trial-and-error experiments with single-factor changes. As a result, it is inefficient to create Cu-Cu2O-CuO catalysts with optimal catalytic performance using the traditional trial-and-error experiment method since the catalytic performance of Cu-Cu2O-CuO catalysts varies on a large number of parameters. Composition optimization of ternary Cu-based catalysts by trial-and-error methods would undoubtedly encounter great difficulties and consume a lot of time and cost. Therefore, it is necessary to take a more efficient approach to achieve composition optimization of ternary Cu-based. Data-based machine learning (ML), a technology that incorporates several academic disciplines, is performed to create a quantitative structure-property relationship (QSPR) model [14,16] between a material's desired properties and its component parts, atomic structure, electronic structure, and energy parameters, as a result of the expansion of experimental data in the field of materials science [17,18]. Therefore, it might be employed to anticipate the characteristics of materials, speeding up the investigation of material properties and the development of new materials [19,20]. A number of material parameters, including the elastic modulus of alloys [21–23], the cyclic performance of batteries [24], the adsorption energy of gases [25,26], the band gap of semiconductors [27], and others, have been predicted successfully using machine learning. By investigating the correlations of enormous data, ML is also applied to speed up the creation of new catalysts [28], improve catalytic activity [29], and identify reaction mechanisms [30]. Similarly, ML approach can learn the quantitative relationship between the multiple compositions of ternary Cu-based catalysts and SM2. Through ML approach, it is possible to break through the limitation of the lack of catalytic mechanism, optimizing the composition of catalysts with less time and experimental cost. The appropriate algorithms, parameters, and descriptors, however, differ amongst various catalytic systems. There is currently no work using ML approach to study Rochow-Müller reaction catalysts, which makes it challenging to collect data and choose features. While ML models can establish the quantitative relationship that exists between inputs and outputs, the specific mathematical form of that relationship cannot be expressed explicitly. There is often a trade-off between the prediction performance and interpretability of ML models [31]. The more advanced the prediction ability of a model, the more complex its structure often becomes, making it difficult to understand. Thus, additional tools are needed to link data-driven ML models to materials science knowledge. Feature selection allows for the removal of unimportant and redundant features, which not only improves the prediction performance, but also provides an interpretation of the prediction results with a combination of material science. The explanation of the prediction results through experimental characterization can provide theoretical support in a materials science perspective. Presently, we first construct a prediction model by machine learning for SM2 of Cu-based Rochow-Müller catalysts, with the dataset being made of data acquired from practical experiments and published literatures. To obtain the most appropriate modeling and determine how catalytic characteristics affect SM2, a variety of ML algorithms are applied, including linear model, support vector machine, random forest, etc. In order to screen out catalysts with the excellent SM2 from extensive composition and structure space, the catalyst compositions with the highest SM2 are subsequently identified using the GA approach based on the SM2 prediction model. Finally, the catalytic mechanism of ternary Cu-based catalyst is discussed by ranking the importance of the characteristics that affect SM2 output from machine learning. The structure of this study is shown in Fig. 1. 2 Machine learning methods Machine learning framework in this paper is processed using the following packages with Python environment: Numpy and Pandas for data processing, Scikit-learn for machine learning modeling and prediction, and Geatpy for composition optimization. 2.1 Data collection Because the experimental data collected from the literatures was limited and mostly inconsistent in reaction settings and criteria. Thus, the ML dataset was consisted of not only the data collected from literature databases like Cnki and ScienceDirect with the same experimental settings including reaction time, reaction temperature, catalyst dosage and flowing rate of chloromethane as this study, but also data obtained from present trials. After data cleaning, 62 data were added to the dataset that contained information on the weight percentages of Cu, Cu2O, and CuO, the weight percentage of promoter (Zn, Sn, and P), average particle size D50, and SM2. 9 of the data were collected from other literatures and 53 were from experiments. During the establishment stage of the feature set, features that may have an impact on SM2 should be collected as widely as possible. Taking into account the gas-solid catalysis theory and the previously proposed Rochow-Müller reaction mechanism, additional parameters that could affect the SM2 of the catalyst were introduced as machine learning features. It includes structural, electronic and chemical features such as band gap, formation energy, covalent radius, and lattice energy, and electronic features related to electrons such as number of valence electrons, electronegativity, electron affinity energy and ionization energy. These features associated with chemisorption and electron transfer tend to have a significant impact on the catalytic reaction process. Nevertheless, the roles of these features in the field of Rochow-Müller reactions have not been studied in depth. Table 1 presents the selected variables along with the original data that were gathered from Ptable(ptable.com), Materials Project(www.materialsproject.org), Atomly(www.atomly.net), Matminer(https://hackingmaterials.lbl.gov/matminer/), and other databases. The calculation method and source of each feature are listed in Table S1. In this work, every feature has a wide range of data, which may have an effect on the speed of convergence and the accuracy of the modeling. In that case, it is necessary to standardize the data for each feature by Eq. (2): (2) Z i = x i − x ̅ s where x i is the initial value of each data point; x ̅ is the average value; s is the standard deviation; z i is the standardized value of x i . 2.2 Modeling and evaluation For a specific machine learning problem, it is often unknown which algorithm has the best performance until the model is trained. Therefore, it is necessary to adapt different classes of ML algorithms and compare their prediction performance on the problem. In this work, Lasso regression (LASSO), supporting vector regression (SVR), random forest regression (RFR), adaptive boosting regression (ABR) and extreme gradient boosting tree regression (XGBoost, XBR) were selected to predict SM2. With grid search method, the hyperparameters of regression algorithms were sequentially adjusted in steps within a specified range to find the parameters combination with the highest fitting accuracy the lowest root mean square error. In addition, the Stacking method was used to further improve the fitting accuracy by aggregating several weak learners in the first layer into one strong learner in the second layer, as shown in Fig. 2. In the first layer, base learners were trained on the dataset and output their respective prediction results. The outputs of the base learners are composed into a new matrix, which is fed into the secondary learner. The secondary learner usually employs a simple algorithm such as weighted averaging or voting on the inputs from the base learners to form the final prediction. In this work, SVR, RFR, ABR and XBR were chosen as base learners. With the two-layer construction, the secondary learner can further learn on the basis of the base learners, combining and evaluating the learning results of the base learners to further improving the generalization performance [32]. In order to improve the generalization performance of the model and prevent overfitting, the dataset was divided as mutually exclusive training set, testing set and validation set. ML model learns the relationship between features and target performance on the training set. Subsequently, an initial evaluation of the prediction performance is conducted on the validation set and hyperparameters are adjusted based on the performance. Finally, the generalization performance of the model is tested on the testing set. In general, and especially for small datasets, the validation set is not necessary. The size of dataset in this study was small, and directly dividing the training set and testing set would further reduce the size of the dataset. To divide the training and testing sets as efficiently as possible while maintaining the size of the training set, the leave-one-out method was chosen for cross-validation. When the size of the dataset is less than 30, the leave-one-out method is usually considered to be the most applicable splitting method [33]. For any data point D i in dataset D , leave-one-out method selected it as the testing set, and the remaining subset D / D i as the training set. All the data in dataset D were subjected to the above operation and trained sequentially. The average result on all testing sets was taken as the test result. The prediction performance of each machine learning model was evaluated by mean square error (MSE), mean absolute error (MAE), goodness of fit (R2) and Pearson correlation coefficient (PC). They are calculated as follows: (3) MSE = ∑ i = 1 n y i − y ˆ i 2 n (4) MAE = ∑ i = 1 n y i − y ˆ i n (5) R 2 = 1 − ∑ i = 1 n y i − y ˆ i 2 ∑ i = 1 n y i − y ̅ i 2 (6) PC = ∑ i = 1 n y i − y ˆ i ̅ y i − y ̅ i ∑ i = 1 n y i − y i ̅ 2 ∑ i = 1 n y i − y ˆ i 2 where y i is the actual value and y ˆ i is the predicted value. When used as a loss function for evaluating model performance, MSE has a faster convergence rate than MAE, but is also more sensitive to outliers. Comparatively, MAE is more robust in the face of outliers [34,35]. It is common to use both evaluation metrics together to judge the prediction accuracy of the models in practice. A machine learning model with good prediction accuracy should have lower MSE and MAE, as well as higher R2 and PC. 2.3 Feature selection As many variables as feasible that could impact SM2 were taken into account as input characteristics in the data gathering section. However, with small datasets, feature dimension typically determines how accurate machine learning models are in making predictions. Because having too many or too few features could reduce the model's ability to predict the future accurately, which could be especially noticeable when working with small datasets. To examine the linear relationships between characteristics in this work, the Pearson correlation coefficient was introduced. The Pearson coefficient between the two features is calculated as: (7) PC = ∑ i = 1 n x i − x ̅ i y i − y ̅ i ∑ i = 1 n x i − x i ̅ 2 ∑ i = 1 n y i − y ̅ i 2 where PC is Pearson correlation coefficient, xi,yi are values of features. Correlation value closed to 1 or −1 between features indicates that either feature can take the place of the other without significantly altering the vital information. Besides, Recursive Feature Elimination(RFE) was adopted to eliminate redundant features. RFE is an embedded feature selection algorithm that attempts to improve generalization performance by removing the least important features [36]. During execution, RFE iteratively removes one of the features with the smallest weight based on the feature ranking until the convergence condition is met. The number of features when RFE converges is determined by feature importance ranking of the tree models. The Gini impurity splitting nodes at each feature are used by the tree models to determine how important each feature is. 2.4 Composition optimization After building a model of catalyst composition-SM2 relationship, the genetic algorithm(GA) was used to search the composition with the highest SM2 in the composition space based on the prediction model. The process for composition optimization with GA is shown in Fig. 3. Target compositions to be optimized were considered as input features to the genetic algorithm. The rest of features in the feature set that prediction model needed were generated by the feature generation function. GA transformed input features into binary information as individual chromosomes in a population through coding. The quantitative relationship between composition and SM2 obtained from the prediction model will be used as a fitness function to determine the corresponding SM2 of individual populations based on their compositions. Through selection, individuals with higher fitness are chosen to produce the next generation. Through crossover, two individuals exchange parts of each other's chromosome sequences to produce a new individual. Through mutation, a certain segment of an individual's chromosome sequence is altered, making it possible for the individual to jump out of the local optimal solution. Populations continued to spawn new generations until the fitness function cannot be improved or the number of evolutionary generations reaches the preset value. 3 Experimental methods 3.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared by ball-milling. Cu powders with a mesh size of less than 325, Cu2O powders made by diffusion, CuO powders, and alloy powders with promoters such CuZn20, CuSn10, and CuP8 were combined in the appropriate amounts. A vertical ball mill was filled with mixed powders, and 6 mm Zirconia balls were used to ball mill the mixture until the ball to powder weight ratio was 10:1. The combined powders were re-mixed for three minutes at a rotating speed of 15 Hz before to ball milling. 3.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were performed by Rigaku SmartLab. Chemical environment analysis of sample surfaces was performed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) by Thermo Fisher Scientific spectrograph. The valence band spectrum of XPS was used to calculate the valence band energy levels of the samples. The UV-Vis absorption spectra of the samples were recorded by Hitachi U4150 and the bandwidths of the samples were calculated. The content of Cu, Cu2O and CuO in the catalyst samples was determined by titration. 0.3 g catalyst sample was dispersed in a with 120 ML acetonitrile. 40 ML HCL was added to the conical flask while it was kept shaking. After rapid vacuum filtration, the mixture was separated into a precipitate and a solution. 160 ML deionized water was added into the filtrated solution, followed by being titrated by 0.02 mol·L−1 KMnO4. As shown in formula n, the content of Cu2O was calculated by the amount of consumed KMnO4. The precipitate was dissolved in 20 ML FeCl3 with 20 ML MnSO4 and 100 ML deionized water and titrated by 0.02 mol·L−1 KMnO4. Similarly, the content of Cu was also calculated by the amount of consumed KMnO4 as Eqs. 8–10. The content of CuO is the residual amount after subtracting the content of Cu and Cu2O from the total sample. (8) 8 H + + 5 C u + + Mn O 4 − → 5 C u 2 + + M n 2 + + 4 H 2 O (9) Cu + 2 F e 3 + → C u 2 + + 2 Fe 2 + (10) 8 H + + 5 Fe 2 + + Mn O 4 − → 5 Fe 3 + + Mn 2 + + 4 H 2 O 3.3 Catalytic measurement The catalytic performance of the catalyst was tested by reaction to verify the reliability of ML model. The process of Rochow-Müller reaction was carried out in a fixed bed reactor as shown in Fig. 4. 10.0 g Si powders and 0.5 g catalyst were grinded to mix homogeneously and placed in a glass reaction tube. The reaction tube was heated to 325 ℃ at a rate of 5 ℃·min−1 after being purged by chloromethane at a flow rate of 25 ML·min−1 for 30 minutes. The reaction was maintained for 24 hours under 325 ℃ and chloromethane purging incessantly. The gaseous reaction product was cooled down to liquid and dissolved in methylbenzene by a cooling circulation system under 1.1 ℃. Composition of the product was analyzed by gas chromatography. The main compositions, including M1H, M2H, M1, M2, M3, other by-products with low boiling points (LBR) and high boiling points (HBR), were detected by a gas chromatograph. Since the stationary phase in the chromatography column has a different adsorption capacity for each component of the product, the components will be separated from each other and detected by gas chromatograph. SM2 is determined by the percentage of area of the peak corresponding to M2 in the chromatogram as Eq. 11: (11) S M 2 = A M 2 ∑ i = M 1 , M 2 , M 3 , M 1 H , M 2 H , LBR , HBR A i × 100 % where Ai represents the peak area occupied by composition i in the gas chromatogram. 4 Result and discussion 4.1 Result of feature selection Pearson correlation coefficient shows the correlation between the input features. As shown in Fig. 5, the following features are highly correlated with each other: Ef_mean, R_mean, Xp_mean, N_mean, Xa_mean, Ei_mean, D_Ef and D_Xp, which means that they provide a lot of repetitive information. Moreover, there is no significant association found between SM2 and any input feature, indicating a complicated and nonlinear link between the catalysts' structure and composition and SM2. Gini impurity is applied to measure sample consistency after branching of decision tree models. For decision tree-based integration models ABR, RFR and XBR, Gini impurity can be also used to evaluate the importance of features to the target performance. Fig. 6 shows the feature importance ranking of these three algorithms. As can be seen from the figure, features with higher correlation coefficients such as Ef_mean, R_mean, and Xp_mean also have lower feature importance. The 9 approximately most essential features out of all the features were picked to be kept in accordance with the distribution of feature importance. It is worth noting that most of the D50 average particles of catalysts prepared in this study were distributed in the range of 1.5–2.5 μm, implying that the change in D50 actually has a rather limited effect on the catalytic performance. D50 was consequently taken out of the feature set. RFE method is used to remove features that do not have a significant impact on model performance, and the convergence condition is set to the remaining 9 features based on the feature importance distribution. The results of RFE feature selection based on different models are shown in Table 2. It is clear that the results of the RFE are generally similar across different models and are also compatible with the findings of the feature importance ranking. RFE was eventually used to develop a filtered feature set that contained the most important features for SM2. Table 3 displays the prior prediction performance of each model prior to and following feature selection without modifying the combination of hyperparameters to examine the effect of feature selection on model performance. SVR algorithm was additionally incorporated to test the performance change of feature selection on non-decision tree algorithms. Table 3 demonstrates that, following feature selection, R2 and PC both increase while the prediction errors of all models decrease. Among them, R2 and PC have clearly improved. The PC values of RFR and XBR increase from 0.4 to 0.58 and 0.53–0.55, respectively, before feature selection, demonstrating that deleting redundant features could lessen the interference of noise information on the models. The prediction performance of SVR is also greatly enhanced by feature selection, with an increase in R2 from 0.12 to 0.27. It has been proven that feature selection promotes decision tree models as well as non-decision tree models perform better when it comes to generalization. 4.2 Machine learning performance On the basis of feature selection, six machine learning algorithms, LASSO, SVR, ABR, RFR, XBR and stacking, were used to train the formal ternary Cu-based catalysts composition SM2 model by applying the leave-one-out method. Fig. 7 shows the deviation between the predicted and actual values for each algorithm and the prediction performance of each model after hyperparameter adjustment is shown in Table 4. As seen in Table 4, LASSO has the worst predictive performance as a kind of linear algorithm, and the fitting results between predicted and actual values is poor(R2=0.18) among all the algorithms, suggesting a complex nonlinear relationship between the composition of ternary Cu based catalysts and SM2. It is also found that although XBR has many advantages such as effectively avoiding overfitting, handling missing values [37], and outperformed other existing models in many machine learning cases [38], its prediction performance in this study is inferior to that of ABR, RFR and SVR. In machine learning, the "no free lunch" theorem [39] states that there isn't a single best machine learning algorithm that can be used with all datasets. In comparison to other single algorithms, the stacking method, which used many algorithms as base learners, has the lowest error (MSE=18.62,MAE=3.38) and maximum correlation (R2=0.41,PC=0.65). Regardless of the SM2 of the data points, stacking retains a promising prediction accuracy. It demonstrates that stacking integration incorporated the benefits of diverse learners successfully and enhanced prediction performance even on smaller datasets. 4.3 Composition optimization and experimental validation In the optimization problem of this study, there are six compositions to be optimized. It is quite inefficient to attempt to find the optimal composition point by the trial-and-error method due to the unclear catalytic mechanisms. Through the work in above sections, a quantitative relationship model between the composition of ternary Cu-based catalysts and SM2 was obtained. Inputting any compositions of ternary Cu-based catalysts, ML model is able to predict their corresponding SM2 By continually iterating through the catalyst composition space, it is theoretically possible to obtain the compositions with the highest SM2. However, this approach would undoubtedly be time-consuming and computationally expensive. The meta-heuristic algorithms represented by genetic algorithm (GA) could find the optimal compositions more efficiently instead. The process of solving optimization problems by GA can be seen in Fig. 3 in Section 2.4. The mathematical expression of the composition optimization problem for SM2 can be described as: (12) max F ( Cu , Cu 2 O , CuO , Zn , Sn , P ) s .t . 0 ≤ Cu ≤ 40 60 ≤ Cu 2 O ≤ 100 0 ≤ CuO ≤ 40 0 ≤ Zn ≤ 0.3 0 ≤ Sn ≤ 0.3 0 ≤ P ≤ 0.3 Cu + Cu 2 O + CuO ≤ 100 where F is ML prediction model with the Stacking algorithm for SM2. Cu, Cu2O, CuO, Zn, P, Sn are the contents of the catalyst components and promoters. The constraint was set to that the total content of the three Cu species would not exceed 100. The contents of ternary compositions generally considered for industrial production are: Cu, 0–20%; Cu2O, 70–90%; CuO, 10–25% [5,40–42]. The ranges of additives for promoters are: Zn, 0.04–0.2%; Sn, 0.002–0.25%; P, 0.5–5% by mass of Cu [3,43]. In this study, the compositional space was further expanded from the generalized range in order to ensure that compositions with the highest SM2 were found. Composition optimization of ternary Cu-based catalysts was carried out by GA based on the hyperparameter settings in Section 2.4. Fig. 8 shows the average SM2and the SM2 of the optimal individual for each generation of GA. It can be seen that the algorithm converged after 20 generations, proving its ability to effectively solve the combinatorial optimization problem. It is worth noting that due to the presence of penalty terms in the fitness function, the optimized compositions and SM2 obtained would not be consistent with the prediction results of the stacking model. The optimal composition obtained by GA was predicted again by stacking to obtain the final SM2. The optimal compositions and the corresponding SM2 obtained by the genetic algorithm are shown in Table 5. Because the catalyst composition SM2 from ball milling process was not completely controllable, an optimal composition interval was listed. Catalyst sample was prepared with ball milling according to the optimized composition given by GA. The composition of the experimentally prepared catalysts was tested by redox titration(shown in Table 5). The result shows that the prepared catalyst composition is basically consistent with the optimized composition, although the ternary composition cannot be precisely controlled. The prepared catalyst was mixed with silica powder and reacted in a fixed bed reaction unit for 24 h. The product was collected and analyzed by gas chromatography to calculate SM2. As shown in Table 5, SM2 of the prepared catalyst according to the optimized combination reaches 82.35%, with a difference of only 0.93% from the predicted value of 82.46%. It means that ML model constructed the quantitative relationship between catalyst compositions and performance quite accurately and was able to reproduce it successfully over a range of untrained samples. The results of the experiment also indicate that efficient performance optimization and composition design of ternary Cu-based catalysts for the Rochow-Müller reaction can be successfully achieved through ML framework. 4.4 Experimental characterization and analysis ML models are typically black box models. There are a large number of nonlinear and complex network structures inside the model, and it is not possible to intuitively output a quantitative expression of the relationship between features and performance [44]. As a result, ML is often perceived as lacking in interpretability. However, ML models can still provide guidance on design principles for materials. The features selected by the feature selection are believed to have a significant impact on the target performance. By analyzing these features, it is expected that key information about the catalytic reaction process can be derived. According to the results of feature selection, the average band gap, the variance of band gap and the average number of valence electrons which are directly related to the electronic structure of the catalyst are key features to SM2. Based on the selected important features, it can be assumed that the electronic structure and valence changes induced by the mutual contact of different Cu species are exactly the essence of ternary synergistic effect. Material science interpretations of ML features are provided by carrying out confirmatory experimental characterization of the prediction results and analyzing the effect of feature changes on material properties based on characterization. In order to reveal the role of the average number of valence electrons in the reaction process, XRD was used to verify the changes of the physical phase of the catalyst after 24 h of reaction. The XRD patterns of the contact masses before and after reaction were shown in Fig. 9. The mass ratio of Si powder to catalyst that composed the contact mass is 10:0.5, so the patterns are dominated by diffraction peaks of Si with 2θ values of 28.3°, 56.1°, 69.1°, 76.3° and 87.9°. Meanwhile, diffraction peaks of Cu, Cu2O and CuO are detected at 2θ values of 42.5°,47.3° and 36.3°, proving the presence of ternary compositions. Fig. 9(b) reveals the XRD patterns of Cu3Si, Cu and CuO. A diffraction peak of Cu3Si was detected in the contact mass at 43.2° after reaction, which was almost absent before reaction, proving that the optimized ternary composition effectively promoted the generation of the active phase during the catalytic adsorption process. In the most accepted view, Cu3Si is believed to be produced from the reactive intermediate species Cu* in the 0-valence state. The amount of change in Cu3Si before and after the reaction was significantly greater than the amount of change in Cu, proving that there were Cu species in other valence states converted to Cu*. Thus, the average number of valence electrons will reflect the amount of Cu+ and Cu2+ of the catalyst, changes in which will affect the formation of Cu* forming the active phase. Electron transfer and reduction processes significantly affect catalytic reactions, which is why the average number of valence electrons is recognized by ML models with different integration algorithms as a structural feature with high importance for SM2. It indicates that constructed ML model successfully captures the important relationship between catalyst composition and performance. ML prediction model points out the important role of average formation energy in SM2, with the importance of the average formation energy and the variance of formation energy exceeding 4% in both ABR and RFR models. This suggests that the atomic binding state of the catalysts also has an impact on the catalytic performance. XPS was applied to analyze the chemical state of the surface elements of catalysts. The numerical fitting result of the XPS spectrum of the optimized catalyst is shown in Fig. 10. There are two sub-bands for chemisorbed oxygen(Oads) with binding energy at about 531.26 eV and lattice oxygen(Olat) connected to Cu ions at about 529.80 eV respectively. On the surface of the optimized catalyst, the atomic ratio of Oads and Olat is calculated as 1.05 based on the peak area, with Oads having a higher value than Olat. It is widely recognized that the bonding energy of a component is usually influenced by its surrounding chemical environment [45]. The ratio of Oads to Olat indicates that the optimized catalyst composition is capable of obtaining superior catalytic performance by changing the state of the Cu-O bonds on the catalyst surface. The Cu-O bond strengths of Cu2O and CuO are reflected by their Ef, so the average formation energy of ternary Cu-based catalysts will affect the proportion of Oads and Olat. The results of GA indicates that the average formation energy of the catalysts could be modulated to increase Oads by adjusting the composition of ternary Cu. According to previous reports, Oads possesses higher reactivity than Olat due to its higher mobility [46]. The formation of Oads also represents the appearance of oxygen vacancies(OV) in the lattice, which benefits further adsorption of CH3Cl on the catalyst surface [47]. The rising concentration of reducible CH3Cl on the surface of the catalyst promotes the reduction of Cu+ to active Cu*, and hence increases the content of the active phase Cu3Si, which is capable of selectively generating M2. However, OV has both positive and negative effects on catalytic activity [48]. OV is capable of increasing the adsorption of CH3Cl as well as absorbing electron-hole pairs to complex them, inhibiting the generation of the reactive intermediate species Cu*. Therefore, GA obtains the average formation energy and Ov concentration values with the highest catalytic activity by adjusting the ratio of ternary components. The results of XPS further enhance the reliability and interpretability of ML model, which proves that it can successfully dig out quantitative relationships between material structure and performance from data. Band gap is a significant structural parameter according to feature importance ranking of different ML models. For ABR model, the average band gap and the variance of band gap account for 9% and 8.1% of the importance, ranking second and third among all 19 features, respectively. For the other two models, the average band gap ranks high among the features similarly. RFE also considers the average band gap as a feature that has a significant impact on SM2. The valence band (VB) energy levels of Cu2O and the optimized catalysts were calculated from the XPS valence band spectra. The VB of Cu2O is 0.56 eV, whereas the VB of the optimized catalyst is 0.33 eV. The VB of the optimized catalyst deviates from Cu2O, which causes an increase in the driving force for enrichment of holes in the valence band of the Cu2O semiconductor in the catalyst. In addition, the optimized catalyst was tested by UV–vis absorption spectroscopy and the corresponding Tauc plot was obtained (shown in Fig. 11(d)). The formula for calculating the band gap from Tauc plot is: (13) αhv 1 / n = B ( hv − E g ) where α is absorption coefficient, hv is Planck's constant, n is 1/2 for direct bandgap semiconductor, v is frequency of incident photon, B is a proportional constant, Eg is band gap. Based on the Tauc plot, the Eg value of the optimized catalyst was calculated. The Eg value of Cu2O was 2.31 eV, while the Eg value of the optimized catalyst was reduced to 2.12 eV. Changes in chemical composition can lead to changes in Eg because the strong interactions between the chemical bonds of the components promote electron transfer at the phase interface, leading to a decrease in the band gap [49]. The narrowed bandgap indicates the formation of a mixed bandgap structure between Cu/Cu2O/CuO [50], which will contribute to the efficient separation of electron-hole pairs. The separated holes will be enriched on the surface of Cu2O under the influence of the mixed bandgap structure, which makes Cu2O electropositive. CH3Cl will be more likely to be trapped on the electropositive surface and subsequently reduce Cu2O to active Cu*. More generated Cu* promotes the formation of Cu3Si and thus improves SM2. Therefore, Eg of the catalyst will vigorously influence its SM2, and this relationship is successfully detected by different ML models. 4.5 Analysis of catalytic mechanism According to the analysis based on machine learning models and experimental characterization, combined with previous researches, the mechanism for the Rochow-Müller catalytic process and ternary synergistic effect has been proposed. In Rochow-Müller catalytic process, the active phase that selectively generates M2 is Cu3Si, which is formed by interdiffusion of active Cu* and Si* at the Cu-Si contact interface. ML model and XRD pattern suggest that Cu* is mainly derived from the reduction of Cu+ under CH3Cl atmosphere, while Si* is produced by the cleaving of the Si-Si bond [6]. In the feature importance ranking, Cu2O is the dominant component in ternary Cu-based catalysts with high SM2. The content of Cu2O will affect the average number of valence electrons and the formation energy of the catalyst, which further affects the Cu+ reduction process and changes the concentration of Cu* produced. As the most vital structural parameter in the quantitative prediction model, the value of band gap will reflect the energy band structure of the catalyst surface and substantially affect its SM2. Due to the different energy band structures of the ternary components, semiconductor junctions are formed at the contact interfaces of both Cu/Cu2O and CuO/Cu2O. ML optimization model can effectively change the contact interface configuration of the ternary catalyst to achieve the highest SM2 by adjusting the composition. The Fermi energy level of the semiconductor Cu2O is at a lower level than that of the metal Cu [51]. When the metals Cu and Cu2O are in contact with each other, both the valence and conduction bands of Cu2O will bend downward. Consequently, a Schottky junction will be formed at the contact interface of Cu/Cu2O (shown in Fig. 12(a)). At the Cu/Cu2O contact interface, the electrons within Cu will migrate towards Cu2O owing to the difference in Fermi energy levels, accordingly leaving holes on Cu surface, until the holes and electrons form an internal electric field preventing the electrons from continuing to migrate. Under the reaction temperature, whenever an electron-hole pair is excited, the electron will jump to the Cu2O conduction band and enter the space charge region, migrating to the Cu interior under the action of the space electric field subsequently. Besides, Cu as a good electronic conductor can serve as a directional conductive pathway for fast and efficient charge transfer, thus inhibiting the complexation of electron-hole pairs [52]. The presence of the Schottky barrier further prevents the migration of electrons from Cu to Cu2O. As a result, the valence band of Cu2O will enrich holes, making Cu2O easier to attract Cl- ions and be reduced to Cu* by electron transfer in the presence of Cl-. The valence electrons provided by Cu2O and CuO will contribute to the reduction process, while the adsorbed oxygen due to the interaction between different compositions further aids in the adsorption of Cl-. As shown in Fig. 12(b), the Cu* generated at the Cu-Si contact interface is dispersed so it is able to effectively diffuse with Si phase to form Cu3Si phase. Cu and Si in Cu3Si will attract Cl- and CH3 + respectively, leading to bond breaking and recombination to generate M2, as shown in Fig. 12(c). As the reaction proceeds, the content of Cu will increase spontaneously. Therefore, only a small amount of Cu is required for the composition of optimized catalyst as the initiator of Rochow-Müller reaction. There is no study that clearly indicates the contribution of CuO in ternary synergism and its specific role in Rochow-Müller reactions. However, ML model shows that the content of CuO is also a major factor affecting the catalytic performance. The contact between Cu2O and CuO will also change the chemical state and band structure of the contact interface, and thus enhance the catalytic performance. CuO is an indirect bandgap semiconductor with a bandgap of 1.7 eV. According to the reports, the valence and conduction band energy levels of CuO are both lower than those of Cu2O [53], leading to a heterojunction with a type-II staggered band structure at the contact interface between CuO and Cu2O [54]. Since electrons have a tendency to migrate to lower energy levels while holes have an opposite tendency to migrate to higher energy levels, the heterojunction structure is also able to increase the concentration of holes on Cu2O. Similarly, the generation of Cu* and Cu3Si active phases is promoted. In addition, CuO has higher reaction stability than Cu2O, so it can also increase the catalytic life while maintaining SM2. The mixed energy band structure consisting of Cu/Cu2O/CuO strongly promotes the formation of the active intermediate species Cu*, which selectively generates M2 through the process of Fig. 12(a)-(c). After the generation of M2, Si is consumed while Cu* is released again. Cu* can continue to diffuse with Si to form Cu3Si again to recycle the reaction or become a Cu phase that loses activity due to mutual agglomeration, which is the reason for the increase of Cu content after reaction. The proposed catalytic mechanism not only explains the synergistic effect of the ternary compositions, but also achieves considerable agreement with ML model conclusions, successfully explaining ML model from the perspective of materials science. It means that decisions on catalyst design and optimization can be guided by results of ML models. Although there is still a lack of in-depth knowledge on the catalytic mechanism of various promoters, machine learning models emphasize the importance of the promoter composition for SM2. According to the optimization results of genetic algorithm, a catalyst with excellent SM2 can be obtained by adding only Zn and P within 0.05% and Sn within 0.15% to the catalyst composition. It is generally believed that Zn is beneficial for CH3Cl adsorption on the surface of the catalyst, effectively eliminating the reaction obstruction caused by the harmful substances in Si powder, and increasing the Si concentration on the surface of active Cu3Si. There is a synergy effect between Sn and Zn when they are added to the reaction system together, lowering the melting point and surface tension of Cu3Si, in order to enhance the diffusion ability of Cl in the active phase of the catalyst, so that the catalyst can form more active centers [55]. P can increase the diffusion rate of Cu, promoting the formation of Cu3Si active phases and improving the Si conversion and SM2 [56]. Therefore, a suitable composition of promoters is also necessary for the improvement of catalytic performance of the catalyst. 5 Conclusions In summary, a prediction model for composition- SM2 of ternary copper-based Rochow-Müller catalysts was developed using machine learning on a small dataset in this study. Firstly, redundant features were eliminated by Pearson correlation coefficient, feature importance ranking and RFE, and key feature sets were identified. LASSO, ABR, SVR, RFR, XBR as well as stacking algorithms using them as base learners were used for training machine learning regression task models. After feature selection and hyper parameter adjusting by grid searching, the prediction performances of all algorithms were improved, among which the stacking algorithm had the best prediction performance with MSE=18.62, MAE=3.38, R2=0.41, and PC=0.65. Secondly, based on the stacking prediction model, the composition with the best SM2 was searched from the composition space according to the genetic algorithm, and an optimized catalyst with SM2 of 82.35% was obtained, with a relative error of 0.93% from the predicted value. Ternary Cu-based catalyst compositions with high SM2 were successfully designed by machine learning framework. In addition to this, the model shows that the average band gap, formation energy, and number of valence electrons of the catalyst are important factors in influencing SM2. Finally, combining the above features given by ML framework with experimental characterization and validation, a Rochow-Müller catalytic reaction process and a ternary synergistic mechanism are presented from the viewpoint of valence electron number, defect state and band gap. The main reasons for improving the activity of Cu2O are: (1) the Schottky barrier at the Cu/Cu2O contact interface, and (2) the type-II staggered band structure at the Cu2O/CuO contact interface generated due to the difference in bandgap. The synergistic effect increases the concentration of holes on the surface of Cu2O, making it more susceptible to reduction to Cu*, which leads to the formation of the active phase Cu3Si. As a result, M2 can be generated more selectively. The proposed catalytic theory successfully provides a materials science corroboration for ML framework. This study establishes a complete ML framework with SM2 prediction and composition optimization for Rochow-Müller ternary Cu-based catalysts, showing that machine learning can provide effective guidance for Rochow-Müller catalysts. In addition, this study also demonstrates the general idea of applying ML methods to accelerate the design of novel catalysts: ML prediction models can capture the quantitative relationship between catalyst structure and performance. With prediction models, the catalytic performance of any catalyst can be quickly obtained without experiments. Optimization algorithm can select the composition with the best performance from the candidate composition space, efficiently achieving the development of novel catalysts. coredata.dc:description: To find ternary Cu-based catalysts (Cu/Cu2O/CuO) compositions with the highest M2 selectivity(SM2) in Rochow-Müller reaction, a machine learning (ML) framework including prediction and optimization models was created. The Stacking integration approach was used to describe the relationship between the catalyst's structures features and SM2 for prediction model. Further, the composition space was effectively searched for compositions with the highest SM2 by optimization model with the genetic algorithm (GA) in the base of prediction model. Finally, the greatest SM2 catalyst compositions were effectively suggested by the ML framework, and the constructed catalyst had an SM2 of 82.35%, with a relative error of only 0.93% from the predicted value. ML model combined with experimental characterization was used to infer the synergistic mechanism of the ternary Cu-based catalysts. Cu/Cu2O and Cu2O/CuO contact surfaces can create heterojunction and Schottky junction structures, respectively, to facilitate the transport of electron-hole pairs and the formation of active spices. ML framework achieved compositional optimization of catalysts and were successfully integrated with materials science theory.
coredata.dc:title: A machine-learning-based composition design of ternary Cu-based Rochow-Müller catalyst with high M2 selectivity
